text: And blame the iceberg
author: DSORennie

text: Thank you for remembering! You are hired as my PR strategist whenever your other duties permit
author: DSORennie

text: Thank you for remembering, you are hired as my agent whenever other duties permit
author: DSORennie

text: VG column from @wangxiangweihk, using his insider-outsider knowledge to skewer CCP elite for sourcing food from the tegong secure farm network, undermining their credibility when food crises break
author: DSORennie

text: Labour deputy leader
author: DSORennie

text: Beyond what this does to NK’s will to denuclearise, when Trump makes sanctions a Q of his whim, rather than principle or rule of intl law, he makes it far harder for US allies to spend political capital, intell resources on sanctions enforcement. Allies appalled, China delighted
author: DSORennie

text: Thank you
author: DSORennie

text: In which I suggest China’s leaders should study early James Bond films, and the dangers of revealing master-plans for world domination just a smidgen too soon... My Chaguan https://www.economist.com/china/2019/03/23/chinas-leaders-should-study-james-bond-films … via @TheEconomist
author: DSORennie

text: Extraordinary times. A public rebuke for his own PM from a thoughtful, moderate Conservative MP and former government minister. Gyimah is anything but a headline-chasing hothead
author: DSORennie

text: Thank you
author: DSORennie

text: Must-read piece. Chinese officials’ support for quack medicine is a public health disaster
author: DSORennie

text: Bubble and squeak
author: DSORennie

text: Excellent on how clashing democratic mandates have caused a deep crisis: "The Brexit referendum was the first time that Britain’s electorate has voted for an outcome with which its MPs disagreed. Nearly 52% of UK voters backed Leave, while nearly 75% of today’s MPs voted Remain."
author: DSORennie

text: BTW @limlouisa and @RadioKitty hope that didn't come across as mansplaining. Just Janansplaining. As a former colleague of his, I think he was taking a swipe at all parents, not just mothers. And as a parent, I think he's wrong
author: DSORennie

text: Ganesh is quoting Cyril Connolly, "Enemies of Promise" (1938): "There is no more somber enemy of good art than the pram in the hall." Connolly was in a crisis about his failure to produce a masterpiece. Self-hating misanthropy, rather than misogyny. Still wrong about parenthood
author: DSORennie

text: Interesting column. Not sure whether @wangxiangweihk is ultimately optimistic or pessimistic that the fawning will be reined in. And whether the problem is sycophancy, or being unsubtle about it
author: DSORennie

text: No, we’re not. The piece starts from the observation that new think-tanks are opening, some of which claim to be independent. It tries to explain how think-tanks can possibly work in an autocracy which says it needs better-quality policy advice but is also obsessed with control
author: DSORennie

text: I don’t think it’s a tough question whether to engage with the machinery of power. If course China corrs should, as long as we put the answers in a broader context, which includes values excluded from state media. And let non-state voices speak. My job is to explain this place.
author: DSORennie

text: To me, asking people who run Chinese think-tanks about those characteristics is a worthwhile exercise. It took months, literally, to get all the interviews, which tells you something. But reporters based in China surely have a chance/duty to explain how the place sees itself
author: DSORennie

text: Trump admin constantly uses weighty language lightly. If we take the US Sec of State at face value, that’s a startling charge.  But what should we think when the US President next says China is smart and its leader is his good friend? Words matter.
author: DSORennie
